data_clean.name: data_clean
data_clean.doc:
process a raw churn data file

Data has 3 states here: `raw`, `cleaned` and `encoded`

* `raw` kept by default, the pipeline begins with a raw data artifact
* `cleaned` kept for charts, presentations
* `encoded` is input for a cross validation and training function

steps (not necessarily in correct order, some parallel)
* column name maps
* deal with nans and other types of missings/junk
* label encode binary and ordinal category columns
* create category ranges from numerical columns
And finally,
* test

Why we don't one-hot-encode here? One hot encoding isn't a necessary
step for all algorithms. It can also generate a very large feature
matrix that doesn't need to be serialized (even if sparse).
So we leave one-hot-encoding for the training step.

What about scaling numerical columns? Same as why we don't one hot
encode here. Do we scale before train-test split?  IMHO, no.  Scaling
before splitting introduces a type of data leakage.  In addition,
many estimators are completely immune to the monotonic transformations
implied by scaling, so why waste the cycles?

TODO: 
    * parallelize where possible
    * more abstraction (more parameters, chain sklearn transformers)
    * convert to marketplace function

train_model.name: train_model
train_model.doc:
train models to predict the timing of events

Although identical in structure to other training functions, this one
requires generating a 'Y' that represents the age/duration/tenure of
the obervation, designated 'tenure' here, and a binary labels columns that
represents the event of interest, churned/not-churned.

In addition, there is a strata_cols parameter, representing a list of
stratification (aka grouping) variables.

parameters.name: context
parameters.doc: the function context

parameters.name: dataset
parameters.doc: ("data") name of raw data file

parameters.name: event_column
parameters.doc: ground-truth (y) labels (considered as events in this model)

parameters.name: time_column
parameters.doc: age or tenure column

parameters.name: encode_cols
parameters.doc: dictionary of names and prefixes for columns that are to hot be encoded.

parameters.name: strata_cols
parameters.doc: columns used to stratify predictors

parameters.name: p_value
parameters.doc: (0.005) max p value for coeffcients selected

parameters.name: sample
parameters.doc: Selects the first n rows, or select a sample starting from the first. If negative <-1, select a random sample

parameters.name: test_size
parameters.doc: (0.25) test set size

parameters.name: valid_size
parameters.doc: (0.75) Once the test set has been removed the training set gets this proportion.

parameters.name: random_state
parameters.doc: (1) sklearn rng seed

parameters.name: models_dest
parameters.doc: destination subfolder for model artifacts

parameters.name: plots_dest
parameters.doc: destination subfolder for plot artifacts

parameters.name: file_ext
parameters.doc: format for test_set_key hold out data

spec.description: cox proportional hazards, kaplan meier plots

parameters.name: context
parameters.doc: the function context

parameters.name: table
parameters.doc: MLRun input pointing to pandas dataframe (csv/parquet file path)

parameters.doc: ground truth column label

train_model.doc:
train an xgboost model.

Note on imabalanced data:  the `imbal_vec` parameter represents the measured
class representations in the sample and can be used as a first step in tuning
an XGBoost model.  This isn't a hyperparamter, merely an estimate that should
be set as 'constant' throughout tuning process.

parameters.doc: the function context

parameters.name: model_type

parameters.name: encode_cols
parameters.doc: dictionary of names and prefixes for columns that are to hot be encoded.

parameters.name: sample
parameters.doc: Selects the first n rows, or select a sample starting from the first. If negative <-1, select a random sample

parameters.name: imbal_vec
parameters.doc: ([]) vector of class weights seen in sample

parameters.name: test_size
parameters.doc: (0.05) test set size

parameters.name: valid_size
parameters.doc: (0.75) Once the test set has been removed the training set gets this proportion.

parameters.name: random_state
parameters.doc: (1) sklearn rng seed

parameters.name: models_dest
parameters.doc: destination subfolder for model artifacts

parameters.name: plots_dest
parameters.doc: destination subfolder for plot artifacts

parameters.name: eval_metrics
parameters.doc: (["error", "auc"]) learning curve metrics

parameters.name: file_ext
parameters.doc: format for test_set_key hold out data

spec.description: train multiple model types using xgboost.

aggregate.name: aggregate
aggregate.doc:
Time-series aggregation function

Will perform a rolling aggregation on {df_artifact}, over {window} by the selected {keys}
applying {metric_aggs} on {metrics} and {label_aggs} on {labels}. adding {suffix} to the 
feature names.

if not {inplace}, will return the original {df_artifact}, joined by the aggregated result.

parameters.name: df_artifact
parameters.doc: MLRun input pointing to pandas dataframe (csv/parquet file path) or a  directory containing parquet files. * When given a directory the latest {files_to_select} will be selected

parameters.name: save_to
parameters.doc: Where to save the result dataframe. * If relative will add to the {artifact_path}

parameters.name: keys
parameters.doc: Subset of indexes from the source dataframe to aggregate by (default=all)

parameters.name: metrics
parameters.doc: Array containing a list of metrics to run the aggregations on. (default=None)

parameters.name: labels
parameters.doc: Array containing a list of labels to run the aggregations on. (default=None)

parameters.name: metric_aggs
parameters.doc: Array containing a list of aggregation function names to run on {metrics}. (Ex: 'mean', 'std') (default='mean')

parameters.name: label_aggs
parameters.doc: Array containing a list of aggregation function names to run on {metrics}. (Ex: 'max', 'min') (default='max')

parameters.name: suffix
parameters.doc: Suffix to add to the feature name, E.g: <Feature_Name>_<Agg_Function>_<Suffix> (Ex: 'last_60_mintes') (default='')

parameters.name: window
parameters.doc: Window size to perform the rolling aggregate on. (default=3)

parameters.name: center
parameters.doc: If True, Sets the value for the central sample in the window, If False, will set the value to the last sample. (default=False)

parameters.name: inplace
parameters.doc: If True, will return only the aggregated results. If False, will join the aggregated results with the original dataframe

parameters.name: drop_na
parameters.doc: Will drop na lines due to the Rolling.

parameters.name: files_to_select
parameters.doc: Specifies the number of *latest* files to select (and concat) for aggregation.

spec.description: Rolling aggregation over Metrics and Lables according to specifications

train_model.name: train_model
train_model.doc:
train models to predict the timing of events

Although identical in structure to other training functions, this one
requires generating a 'Y' that represents the age/duration/tenure of
the obervation, designated 'tenure' here, and a binary labels columns that
represents the event of interest, churned/not-churned.

In addition, there is a strata_cols parameter, representing a list of
stratification (aka grouping) variables.

aggregate.name: aggregate
aggregate.doc:
Time-series aggregation function

Will perform a rolling aggregation on {df_artifact}, over {window} by the selected {keys}
applying {metric_aggs} on {metrics} and {label_aggs} on {labels}. adding {suffix} to the 
feature names.

if not {inplace}, will return the original {df_artifact}, joined by the aggregated result.

parameters.name: df_artifact
parameters.doc: MLRun input pointing to pandas dataframe (csv/parquet file path) or a  directory containing parquet files. * When given a directory the latest {files_to_select} will be selected

parameters.name: save_to
parameters.doc: Where to save the result dataframe. * If relative will add to the {artifact_path}

parameters.name: keys
parameters.doc: Subset of indexes from the source dataframe to aggregate by (default=all)

parameters.name: metrics
parameters.doc: Array containing a list of metrics to run the aggregations on. (default=None)

parameters.name: labels
parameters.doc: Array containing a list of labels to run the aggregations on. (default=None)

parameters.name: metric_aggs
parameters.doc: Array containing a list of aggregation function names to run on {metrics}. (Ex: 'mean', 'std') (default='mean')

parameters.name: label_aggs
parameters.doc: Array containing a list of aggregation function names to run on {metrics}. (Ex: 'max', 'min') (default='max')

parameters.name: suffix
parameters.doc: Suffix to add to the feature name, E.g: <Feature_Name>_<Agg_Function>_<Suffix> (Ex: 'last_60_mintes') (default='')

parameters.name: window
parameters.doc: Window size to perform the rolling aggregate on. (default=3)

parameters.name: center
parameters.doc: If True, Sets the value for the central sample in the window, If False, will set the value to the last sample. (default=False)

parameters.name: inplace
parameters.doc: If True, will return only the aggregated results. If False, will join the aggregated results with the original dataframe

parameters.name: drop_na
parameters.doc: Will drop na lines due to the Rolling.

parameters.name: files_to_select
parameters.doc: Specifies the number of *latest* files to select (and concat) for aggregation.

spec.description: Rolling aggregation over Metrics and Lables according to specifications

feature_selection.name: feature_selection
feature_selection.doc:
Applies selected feature selection statistical functions
or models on our 'df_artifact'.

Each statistical function or model will vote for it's best K selected features.
If a feature has >= 'min_votes' votes, it will be selected.

parameters.name: context
parameters.doc: the function context.

parameters.name: k
parameters.doc: number of top features to select from each statistical function or model.

parameters.name: min_votes
parameters.doc: minimal number of votes (from a model or by statistical function) needed for a feature to be selected. Can be specified by percentage of votes or absolute number of votes.

parameters.name: label_column
parameters.doc: ground-truth (y) labels.

parameters.name: stat_filters
parameters.doc: statistical functions to apply to the features (from sklearn.feature_selection).

parameters.name: model_filters
parameters.doc: models to use for feature evaluation, can be specified by model name (ex. LinearSVC), formalized json (contains 'CLASS', 'FIT', 'META') or a path to such json file.

parameters.name: max_scaled_scores
parameters.doc: produce feature scores table scaled with max_scaler.

parameters.name: sample_ratio
parameters.doc: percentage of the dataset the user whishes to compute the feature selection process on.

parameters.name: output_vector_name
parameters.doc: creates a new feature vector containing only the identifies features.

parameters.name: ignore_type_errors
parameters.doc: skips datatypes that are neither float or int within the feature vector.

parameters.name: is_feature_vector
parameters.doc: bool stating if the data is passed as a feature vector.

train_model.name: train_model
train_model.doc:
train a classifier

An optional cutom model evaluator can be supplied that should have the signature:
`my_custom_evaluator(context, xvalid, yvalid, model)` and return a dictionary of
scalar "results", a "plots" keys with a list of PlotArtifacts, and
and "tables" key containing a returned list of TableArtifacts.

parameters.name: context
parameters.doc: the function context

parameters.name: model_pkg_class
parameters.doc: the model to train, e.g, "sklearn.neural_networks.MLPClassifier", or json model config

parameters.name: dataset
parameters.doc: ("data") name of raw data file

parameters.name: label_column
parameters.doc: ground-truth (y) labels

parameters.name: encode_cols
parameters.doc: dictionary of names and prefixes for columns that are to hot be encoded.

parameters.name: sample
parameters.doc: Selects the first n rows, or select a sample starting from the first. If negative <-1, select a random sample

parameters.name: test_size
parameters.doc: (0.05) test set size

parameters.name: train_val_split
parameters.doc: (0.75) Once the test set has been removed the training set gets this proportion.

parameters.name: test_set_key
parameters.doc: key of held out data in artifact store

parameters.name: model_evaluator
parameters.doc: (None) a custom model evaluator can be specified

parameters.name: models_dest
parameters.doc: ("") models subfolder on artifact path

parameters.name: plots_dest
parameters.doc: plot subfolder on artifact path

parameters.name: file_ext
parameters.doc: ("parquet") format for test_set_key hold out data

parameters.name: random_state
parameters.doc: (1) sklearn rng seed

spec.description: train any classifier using scikit-learn's API

concept_drift_deployer.name: concept_drift_deployer
concept_drift_deployer.doc:
Deploy a streaming Concept Drift detector on a labeled stream
   This function is the Deployment step for the Streaming Concept Drift Detector.
   It will load the selected drift detectors and initialize them with the
   base_dataset's statistics.  Then it will deploy the concept_drift_streaming
   function and pass the models to it for streaming concept-drift detection on top
   of a labeled stream.

parameters.name: context
parameters.doc: MLRun context

parameters.name: base_dataset
parameters.doc: Dataset containing label_col and prediction_col to initialize the detectors

parameters.name: input_stream
parameters.doc: labeled stream to track. Should contain label_col and prediction_col

parameters.name: output_stream
parameters.doc: Output stream to push the detector's alerts

parameters.name: output_tsdb
parameters.doc: Output TSDB table to allow analysis and display

parameters.name: tsdb_batch_size
parameters.doc: Batch size of alerts to buffer before pushing to the TSDB

parameters.name: callbacks
parameters.doc: Additional rest endpoints to send the alert data to

parameters.name: models
parameters.doc: List of the detectors to deploy Defaults to ['ddm', 'eddm', 'pagehinkley'].

parameters.name: models_dest
parameters.doc: Location for saving the detectors Defaults to 'models' (in relation to artifact_path).

parameters.name: pagehinkley_threshold
parameters.doc: Drift level threshold for PH detector Defaults to 10.

parameters.name: ddm_warning_level
parameters.doc: Warning level alert for DDM detector Defaults to 2.

parameters.name: ddm_out_control_level
parameters.doc: Drift level alert for DDM detector Defaults to 3.

parameters.name: label_col
parameters.doc: Label column to be used on base_dataset and input_stream Defaults to 'label'.

parameters.name: prediction_col
parameters.doc: Prediction column to be used on base_dataset and input_stream Defaults to 'prediction'.

parameters.name: hub_url
parameters.doc: hub_url in case the default is not used, concept_drift_streaming will be loaded by this url Defaults to mlconf.hub_url.

parameters.name: fn_tag
parameters.doc: hub tag to use Defaults to 'master'

spec.description: Deploy a streaming Concept Drift detector on a labeled stream
Saves a stream to Parquet and can lunch drift detection task on it
